question: Question_07_(c)
statement:
Suppose that \emph{A} is a symmetric 4x4 matrix with eigenvalues 0, 1,
4, 5. Define a sequence of vectors $\mathbf{x}_n \in \mathbb{R}^4$ by
choosing \textbf{x}\textsubscript{0} at random, and then settings

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{y}_n &= (A-3I)^{-1}\mathbf{x}_{n-1} \\
\mathbf{x}_n &= \mathbf{y}_n/\|\mathbf{y}_{n}\|\end{align*}

for \emph{n = 1, 2, ...}. You then observe that
\textbf{x}\textsubscript{n} converges to

\begin{align*}\mathbf{x}_\infty = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2, 1/2]^T\end{align*}

as $n \to \infty$.

\textbf{(c)} What vector does $\mathbf{y}_n$ converge to?
sols:
Taking the limit \emph{n → $\infty$} on both sides yields

\begin{align*}
\lim_{n \to \infty} \mathbf y_n &= \lim_{n \to \infty} (A-3I)^{-1}\mathbf x_{n-1} \\
&= (A-3I)^{-1} \lim_{n \to \infty}\mathbf x_{n-1} \\
&= (A-3I)^{-1} \mathbf x_\infty \\
&= \eta_3 \mathbf x_\infty \\
&= \mathbf x_\infty = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2, 1/2]^T\end{align*}

We used, from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_07_(a)}{part
(a)}, that $\mathbf x_\infty$ is an eigenvector of
$\displaystyle (A-3I)^{-1}$ with eigenvalue \emph{η\textsubscript{3} =
1}.
hints:
Take the limit $n \to \infty$ on both sides of the definition of
$\mathbf y_n$.
